The term 'Third World' arose during the Cold War to define countries that
remained non-aligned with either NATO (with the United States, Western European
nations and their allies representing the First World), or the Communist Bloc
(with the Soviet Union, the People's Republic of China, Cuba and their allies
representing the Second World). This obsolete terminology provided a way of
broadly categorizing the nations of the Earth into three groups based on social,
political, and economic divisions, which has contributed to political bias. Due
to many of the "Third World countries" being extremely poor, it became a
stereotype such that people commonly refer to undeveloped countries as "third
world countries", often used in a pejorative way. [http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/no-running-water/degrading-third-
world-conditions-one-more-hurdle-for-disabled-man-on-reserve-132369633.html
Usage in a Canadian newspaper] [http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/255320/two-
californias-victor-davis-hanson Usage in the National Review] Over the
last few decades, the term Third World has been mistakenly used interchangeably
with the Global South and Developing Countries to describe poorer countries that
have struggled to attain steady economic development. The politically acceptable
term for the twenty-first century has become the "Emerging World", the Global
South and Developing Countries. Tomlinson, B.R. (2003).
"What was the Third World", Journal of Contemporary History, 38(2):
307â321.

Third World countries were never polled or consulted as to whether or not their
populace and citizenry were in agreement with being listed or referred to as
such; this included most of Africa, Latin America, and Asia. [change]However, it
is considered extremely impolite to use the term Third World anymore and the
correct phrasing may include the Emerging World, Global South or Developing
Countries[change]. Historically, some European countries were part of the non-
aligned movement and a few were and are very prosperous, including Switzerland
and Austria. In the so-called dependency theory of thinkers like Raul Prebisch,
Theotonio dos Santos, and Andre Gunder Frank, the Third World has also been
connected to the world economic division as "periphery" countries in the world
system that is dominated by the "core" countries. Tomlinson, B.R. (2003). "What was the Third World", Journal of
Contemporary History, 38(2): 307â321. Due to the complex history of
evolving meanings and contexts, there is no clear or agreed upon definition of
the Third World and the term is now less popular than it was during the 1970s
and 1980s.
